comment.author: 52603685@N00
comment._content: Of White Star's three ships of this type, the Olympic lasted the longest. The Brittanic was sunk in the Mediterranean while functioning as a hospital ship during WWI. The Olympic was called Old Reliable, and was finally broken up in 1937. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RMS_Olympic

comment.author: 13689532@N06
comment._content: And then, of course, the third ship of the type was the Titanic.

comment.author: 52603685@N00
comment._content: Actually, the Titanic was the second.  The Brittanic (originally called Gigantic) was the third.  After the Titanic went down they put her on hold for a bit, building up the watertight compartments and adding a lot more lifeboats.  She never got a chance to be a passenger liner, though.

comment.author: 80428132@N00
comment._content: Amazing photo! Thank you once again LOC!

comment.author: 25834641@N00
comment._content: Haven't parts of the Olympic been used in a pub in England or Ireland?

comment.author: 23212874@N00
comment._content:
From Wikipedia:
"Olympic's fittings were auctioned off immediately before she was scrapped; some of her fittings, namely those of the First Class Lounge and part of the Aft Grand Staircase, can be found in the White Swan Hotel, in Alnwick, England. Some fittings and panelling also ended up at a Haltwhistle paint factory. The rest of her fittings found homes in scattered places throughout Great Britain."

comment.author: 29079609@N02
comment._content: her arrival on her maiden voyage.

comment.author: 21841229@N05
comment._content: Olympic really is not like Titanic. Lot of difference in their superstructure and believe Olympic is smaller.

comment.author: 61408471@N00
comment._content:
They were actually the same size in their superstructure;
he Titanic closely resembled her older sister Olympic. Although she enclosed more space and therefore had a larger gross register tonnage, the hull was almost the same length as the Olympic's. However, there were a few differences. Two of the most noticeable were that half of the Titanics's forward promenade A-Deck (below the boat deck) was enclosed against outside weather, and her B-Deck configuration was different from the Olympic's.

comment.author: 35769638@N04
comment._content: After reading all the comments, I see the difference between the two ships, Olympic and Titanic. But the initial thought that came to mind was Titanic.  This photo captures the capacity of this ship.

comment.author: 7364400@N04
comment._content: Amazing footage!! The maiden voyage of RMS Olympic arriving on June 21, 1911 in New York. E. J. Smith is actually visible in the bridge of Olympic walking towards the interior of the bridge wearing his white uniform!
